1100407909450682368.text: 12/ There’s more in the podcast worth listening to but I’m out of time. Thanks @rahulvohra for sharing so openly.

1100407908456636416.text: ignore them. Only focus on users who have identified your main benefit and build the features that are missing for them.

1100407906153914372.text: 11/ Remove the cohort of users who answered “not disappointed”. They are so far away from loving your product so you ignore them. Segment the “somewhat disappointed users” along your main benefit (ie: speed for superhuman). For users in this segment who don’t have ‘speed’ benefit

1100407904870506496.text: 10/ Now you focus on what you can do with your product to make more people feel very disappointed without your product to push that percentage above 40%. Analyze survey data on two key questions: why do people love the product? What holds people back from loving the product?

1100407903423389697.text: 9/ Put a word cloud together from the survey answers and start to see what the main benefit of your product is. For superhuman, it was speed.

1100407901808603137.text: 8/ once defined. Goal is to increase % if ppl very disappointed without your product. Narrow your market who fit the archetype who love your product, your HXC. Take the ones that don’t out of your survey. You should see a jump in your product market fit score

1100407900059533312.text: 7/ Use the survey results in step 3 to define your HXC. Construct your own highest expectation customer. Use the 2nd question: the people that love your product the most describe themselves using their own words. This rights your marketing copy & landing page for you

1100407895005585408.text: 5/ Used the “high-expectation customer framework” created by @julessupan who lead early marketing at Dropbox & Airbnb. Framework: the HXC is your most discerning customer, enjoy product for greatest benefit, others will want to emulate them because they seem clever & insightful

1100407893268918277.text:
4/ Q4: How can we improve (product) for you? 

Initial iteration won’t have 40% very disappointed. @SuperhumanCo had 22%. Over half users were “meh” about the product. 

Have to now understand who the people are who really love your product.

1100407891561832448.text: 3/ 4 part survey questions: Q1. How would you feel if you could no longer use (your product)? Very disappointed, somewhat disappointed, not disappointed. Q2: What type of people would most benefit from (your product)? Q3: What is the main benefit you receive from (product)?

1100407890303729664.text: 2/ Borrowed @SeanEllis leading indicator that is benchmarked & predictive: % of users that would feel “very disappointed” if they could no longer use your product. If 40% or more of your users would be disappointed, you’ve found product market fit. Laser in on that metric

1100407889041211392.text: 1/ Most definitions of product / market fit are post-hoc (ie: after you found it) . Not giving you something actionable to focus in on until you’ve found it. So can you find a leading KPI/metric to measure this ?
